DOC.HEAD: Music Syndicate Gives HBO Extension of License
DOC.TEXT: The music syndicate BMI agreed Friday to grant a one-month extension of its license to Home Box Office Inc. at a ``substantially'' higher fee. The fee increase was not disclosed. Company officials couldn't be reached for comment late Friday. BMI sued in federal court Thursday to block unauthorized use of its songs in HBO films, a move that could throw the cable television programmer's schedule into turmoil. BMI asked a U.S. District Court judge to bar HBO from transmitting BMI songs after Sunday, when the companies' licensing agreement ends. It noted that several films in HBO's January schedule include BMI-copyrighted songs. But Judge Vincent Broderick declined to issue an immediate bar, scheduling fuller arguments before another judge, Pierre Leval, on Tuesday. The agreement came in negotiations between representatives of the two companies, BMI said in a statement. BMI said the issues raised in the lawsuit are still unresolved, and that unless the parties could reach agreement in January, the litigation will continue. ``We hope that we can reach agreement on a new long-term license in January,'' Frances W. Preston, BMI's president and chief executive officer, said in the statement. ``But we are prepared to take whatever action is necessary to protect the interests'' of the 100,000 songwriters, composers and music publishers it represents. By law, the writers and publishers are entitled to payment for the public performance of their music.
